etymologies: early 19th century (in the general sense ‘back down, fail utterly’; originally US): perhaps related to funk or to US flink ‘be a coward’, perhaps a variant of flinch

definitions: fail to reach the required standard in (an examination, test, or course of study)

examples.text: I flunked biology in the tenth grade
I didn't flunk but I didn't do too well

shortDefinitions: fail to reach required standard in

definitions: judge (a student or examination candidate) to have failed to reach the required standard
shortDefinitions: judge examination candidate to have failed to reach required standard

definitions: (of a student) leave or be dismissed from school or college as a result of failing to reach the required standard

examples.text: he had flunked out of college

shortDefinitions: (of student) leave or be dismissed from school or college as result of failing to reach required standard
